FRS_Method: GPS CARRIER PHASE STATIC RELATIVE POSITION

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
WASTEWATER TREATMENT PLANT #1



EPA Facility ID # 100000121361





EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



The City of Atlantic Beach Public Utilities Department operates

The City of Atlantic Beach Wastewater Treatment Plant #1 

located at 1100 Sandpiper Lane, Atlantic Beach, Duval 

County Florida. This Plant is one of six water and

Wastewater Plants operated by the City. Wastewater Plant#1 and 

four other plants have quanties of regulated hazardous 

chemicals above the EPA threshold. The City has a unified Risk

Management Program which applies to each plant. Only

Wastewater Treatment Plant #1 operations and policies are 

presented in this Plan.



Wastewater Treatment #1 uses two regulated substances chlorine 

(CAS Number 7782-50-5)in the chlorination process.

The chlorination process consists of the use of chlorine from 

one-ton cylinders to disinfect treated wastewater.

The other regulated substance is Sulfur dioxide (Cas Number 7446-09-5)

used in the dechlorination process.

The sulfur dioxide process consist of the use of sulfur dioxide 

from one-ton clyinders for dechlorination of the treated wastewater.



In order to fulfill the requirements of the Risk Management Program 

(RMP), the facility has developed an accidental

release prevention program and emergency action plan for the facility.

The accidental release prevention program

satisfies the requirements for the USEPA RMP and the Occupational 

Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA)

Process Safety Management (PSM) program.  The prevention program 

ensures that the facility is operated under safe

conditions and that any risk of an accidental release due to human 

error, the facility's prevention program ensures that

operating procedures are current and reviewed annually.Training 

also plays a vital part in the facility's program.

Employees and contractors working near or on the chlorination 

process or sulfur dioxide process are required 

to be trained in the chlorination pro

cess and sulfur dioxide process

and the hazards of chlorine and sulfur dioxide.



To prevent equipment failure that could result in a release, the 

program ensures that equipment inspections, tests, and

preventive maintenance are performed in accordance with accepted 

engineering practices, manufacturer'srecommendations, and 

planned maintenance schedules.  

All chlorine and sulfur dioxide cylinders are examined upon 

delivery and are rejected if there are any signs of damage. In 

addition, equipment pertaining to the chlorine process and

the sulfur dioxide process is visually inspected daily.  



All existing and proposed future chlorination and sulfur dioxide

equipment have been designed according to applicable

standards and codes.The facility maintains records and documentation 

on equipment inspection and tests. Precautions 

are taken to ensure that new equipment and processes are inspected 

and tested, that all changes on the process are authorized, and employees

 are informed of changes.



The facility performed a Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) to address 

the hazards in the chlorination and sulfur dioxide 

process to evaluate and control where potential for a chlorine or

sulfur dioxide release exists.  

Employees were involved in determining hazards of the process and 

subsequent consequences. The chlorination

and sulfur dioxide process was found to be operating safely and no

changes were recommended.



Active employee participation will ensure the success of the RMP 

at the facility.  Employees have been assigned various

tasks to ensure that all elements of the RMP are implemented. 

The facility has developed management forms to

assist employees in recording and documenting the various elements 

of the RMP.



At the time of the submittal of this Risk Management Program, there

have been no accidental releases of chlorine

or sulfur dioxide at this facility in the past five years.However, 

in the event that there is an accident

al release of 

chlorine, or sulfur dioxide an Emergency Action Plan has been written

 

in compliance with 29 CFR 1910.38.  The facility is 

also included in the community emergency response plan. Employees at

 

the facility do not respond to accidental releases

of chlorine, or sulfur dioxide but coordinate with outside responders.

  

Therefore, an Emergency Response

Program is not required for the facility.  In the event that a chlorine 

or sulfur dioxide release occurs, all employees 

are required to evacuate the process area and report the incident. 

The emergency action plan consists of evacuation

procedures,facility emergency numbers, and coordination with the City 

of Jacksonville Fire Department. The plan also addresses

notification procedures to the public and the local emergency 

response agency.
